dialog_nodes.title: Number of cases in my area

values.text: You can view the number of cases anywhere in the world on the weather.com Covid-19 page

dialog_nodes.title: What is the mortality rate for Covid-19?

values.text: The CDC updates their tracking on a daily basis. In order to get the most up to date information you should check the CDC website
You're welcome!  Let me know if I can help answer any other questions.

dialog_nodes.title: What is the role of the World Health Organization?

values.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international organization to help combat disease within the United Nations system. You can find out more about WHO at who.int.

dialog_nodes.title: Should I wear a mask in public?

values.text:
The CDC recommends wearing a cloth face covering in public settings where social distancing may be difficult to maintain. Please refer to the CDC web site for more information on face coverings and general guidance on protecting yourself and others.
Healthcare workers caring for patients suspected to have Covid-19 also need to wear face-masks to prevent additional spread of Covid-19.
If you have a surplus of N95 masks or surgical masks, consider donating them to a local hospital.

dialog_nodes.title: How should I wash my hands properly?

values.text: The CDC recommends washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, being sure to scrub all around and under fingernails, and finally drying with an air dryer or clean towel. If you do not have access to soap or running water, you can use a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol concentration. You can find more information on the CDC's hand-washing recommendations here.

To qualify for TANF, a person must:
  • Be pregnant or have a child under age 19 who lives with them. A child who is 18 must be a full-time high school student. A pregnant woman (and her husband, if he lives with her) may qualify for help, even if they don't have any other children.
  • Live in Arkansas. You can be homeless and still qualify.
  • Be a U.S. citizen or meet certain immigration requirements.
  • Develop a plan for becoming self-sufficient and follow it.
Learn more.

input.text: How do I apply for TANF?

values.text:
Work First aims to shorten the length of time families receive assistance by making work mandatory and limiting how long a family can receive cash assistance. To receive Work First Family Assistance parents must sign a Mutual Responsibility Agreement (MRA)/Outcome Plan.
After moving into the work components of the program families can continue receiving benefits for up to 24 months. In most cases families who have reached the 24-month limit cannot receive Work First Family Assistance for another three years. Federal law sets a 60-month cumulative lifetime limit for receiving these benefits.
Read More.

input.text: How much can I expect to receive for TANF?

values.text: In the last 14 days, <? $self == True ? "have you": "has the person of concern" ?> been exposed to a COVID-19 person?

Answer 'Yes' if any of the following are true:
  • Live with someone who has COVID-19
  • Had close contact with someone who has COVID-19 (for 10 minutes, I was within 6 feet or 2 meters of someone who’s sick or exposed to a cough or sneeze)
  • Been near someone who has COVID-19 (I was at least 6 feet or 2 meters away or more and was not exposed to a sneeze or cough)

dialog_nodes.title: How is Covid different from other illnesses?

values.text: The World Health Organization's Director-General gave a great overview of the differences between Covid and many commonly known illnesses, you can read all kinds of interesting details in the summary.

dialog_nodes.title: Where can I buy a mask?

values.text:
Manufacturers around the world are working hard to produce more face-masks and supply them to hospitals as quickly as possible. Because hospitals are in short-supply, they are taking precedence over orders to supply the retail market.
If you are sick and need a face-mask to prevent spreading the illness to others, the CDC recommends improvising with a scarf or a bandana if you do not have or cannot purchase a face-mask.

Work First can help families stay off public assistance and encourage them to save by helping to make sure they are better off working than on welfare.
The change from Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) to Work First in 1996 encompassed an increase in resource limits to ease the burden on low-income families. The North Carolina General Assembly raised income eligibility limits for families who receive subsidized child care to help families stay employed.
Counties also provide services such as transportation, child care, financial counseling, short-term training and child and family enrichment services to families whose income is at or below 200 percent of the federal poverty level.
Families leaving WFFA for work may receive a job bonus payment for up to three months.
Learn more.

input.text: How do I apply for TANF?

values.text:
For Standard Counties, the State Department of Health and Human Services has set uniform policies for determining eligibility, providing benefits, and ensuring fair and equitable treatment. Applicants or recipients who wish to contest a decision adversely affecting their receipt of Work First cash assistance, or workers contending a breach of the non-displacement in work activity provision of federal law, may appeal in accordance with N.C.G.S. Sec. 108A-79 (N.C.G.S. 108A-79). Families are informed of their right to appeal and are provided with copies of Work First policy upon request.
Electing Counties, as required by State law, have established a local appeals process that substantially complies with the appeals process outlined in N.C.G.S. Sec.108A-79 (N.C.G.S. 108A-79). For Electing Counties, all appeals for Work First are heard locally, not by the State Division of Social Services. Applicants and recipients with disabilities and language interpretation/translation needs are provided with reasonable accommodations and services to assist them in participating in the appeals process if requested.
Read more.

values.text:
If you are currently studying abroad, you should work with the program administrator to determine next steps and, if applicable, find out how they plan to facilitate your return home. If you do opt to return to the United States, you may need to stay home for 14 days and avoid all contact with others. You can find more information about returning from international travel on the CDC's website here.

dialog_nodes.title: Is there a vaccine for COVID-19?

values.text:
To date, there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat COVID-2019. However, those affected should receive care to relieve symptoms. People with serious illness should be hospitalized. Most patients recover thanks to supportive care.
Possible vaccines and some specific drug treatments are under investigation. They are being tested through clinical trials. WHO is coordinating efforts to develop vaccines and medicines to prevent and treat COVID-19.
The most effective ways to protect yourself and others against COVID-19 are to frequently clean your hands, cover your cough with the bend of elbow or tissue, and maintain a distance of at least 1 meter (3 feet) from people who are coughing or sneezing. For more information visit the World Heath Organization's website.

dialog_nodes.title: What happens when the hospital is full?

values.text:
Listen to and follow the directions of your state and local authorities.
Not all patients with COVID-19 require hospital admission. Patients whose clinical presentation warrants in-patient clinical management for supportive medical care should be admitted to the hospital under appropriate isolation precautions.
The decision to monitor these patients in the inpatient or outpatient setting should be made on a case-by-case basis. This decision will depend not only on the clinical presentation, but also on the patient’s ability to engage in self-monitoring, the feasibility of safe isolation at home, and the risk of transmission in the patient’s home environment.
For more information visit here or here .

dialog_nodes.title: How long can I get paid sick leave if I have Covid 19?

values.text:
The Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA) requires that certain employers give two weeks (up to 80 hours) of paid leave to employees experiencing Covid-19 symptoms and seeking a medical diagnosis.
Additionally, if you are unable to work because you are caring for someone with Covid-19 or have a child whose school was closed, you may be eligible for additional time off.
Additional information about eligibility under the FFCRA can be found on the Department of Labor website here.

Work First aims to shorten the length of time families receive assistance by making work mandatory and limiting how long a family can receive cash assistance. To receive Work First Family Assistance parents must sign a Mutual Responsibility Agreement (MRA)/Outcome Plan. After moving into the work components of the program families can continue receiving benefits for up to 24 months. In most cases families who have reached the 24-month limit cannot receive Work First Family Assistance for another three years. Federal law sets a 60-month cumulative lifetime limit for receiving these benefits.
Read More.

input.text: How do I apply for TANF?

values.text:
All Work First cash assistance payments are issued by electronic funds transfer (EFT). The two methods of issuance are direct deposit to a financial institution or electronic benefit transfer (EBT) card. Direct deposit allows for the monthly Work First cash assistance payment to be electronically deposited to a personal savings or checking account of the case head.
There may be fees associated with direct deposit that are imposed by the financial institution. These fees are the responsibility of the recipient. The financial institution cannot impose charges for an account that it does not impose on its other customers for that same type of account. EBT is an electronic system that allows recipients to access their benefits with a plastic card, similar to a bank card.
Read more.

dialog_nodes.title: How can I help others affected by the coronavirus?

values.text:
There are many ways to help out during this crisis. If you know someone who is elderly or at high risk of complications with Covid-19, you can offer to help them with groceries or other necessities. You can also volunteer to help out at a local food bank.
If you are a health care professional, you may also be able to help out on the front lines, as many hospitals are facing staffing shortages as a result of the quick escalation of Covid-19. You can reach out to local hospitals to see if they are accepting volunteers or hiring.
In addition to volunteering, there is significant need for the following donations:
  • Food items
  • Cleaning supplies
  • Toilet paper
  • Hand Sanitizer
  • Money
  • Blood

Many hospitals are also struggling to keep up their stock of personal protective equipment (PPE). If you have any of the following unopened and unused items, consider donating them to a local hospital:
  • N95 masks
  • Surgical masks
  • Face shields and protective eyewear
  • Disposable gloves

On February 11, 2020 the World Health Organization announced an official name for the disease that is causing the 2019 novel coronavirus outbreak, first identified in Wuhan China. The new name of this disease is coronavirus disease 2019, abbreviated as COVID-19. In COVID-19, ‘CO’ stands for ‘corona,’ ‘VI’ for ‘virus,’ and ‘D’ for disease. Formerly, this disease was referred to as “2019 novel coronavirus” or “2019-nCoV”.

There are many types of human coronaviruses including some that commonly cause mild upper-respiratory tract illnesses. COVID-19 is a new disease, caused be a novel (or new) coronavirus that has not previously been seen in humans. The name of this disease was selected following the World Health Organization (WHO) best practice for naming of new human infectious diseases.

dialog_nodes.title: Am I at risk to get Covid-19?

values.text: According to the CDC:

COVID-19 is a new disease and there is limited information regarding risk factors for severe disease. Based on currently available information and clinical expertise, older adults and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions might be at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19. Based upon available information to date, those at high-risk for severe illness from COVID-19 include:
  • People aged 65 years and older
  • People who live in a nursing home or long-term care facility
Other high-risk conditions could include:
  • People with chronic lung disease or moderate to severe asthma
  • People who have heart disease with complications
  • People who are immunocompromised including cancer treatment
  • People of any age with severe obesity (body mass index [(BM]I)≥40) or certain underlying medical conditions, particularly if not well controlled, such as those with diabetes, renal failure, or liver disease might also be at risk
  • People who are pregnant should be monitored since they are known to be at risk with severe viral illness, however, to date data on COVID-19 has not shown increased risk

dialog_nodes.title: Can I return to the United States?

values.text:
If you are returning to the US from international travel, the CDC recommends following these guidelines.
Stay home for 14 days from the time you returned from international travel. During this 14-day period, take these steps to monitor your health and practice social distancing:
-Take your temperature with a thermometer two times a day and monitor for fever. Also watch for cough or trouble breathing. -Stay home and avoid contact with others. Do not go to work or school. -Do not take public transportation, taxis, or ride-shares. Keep your distance from others (about 6 feet or 2 meters).
